description: On March 19, 2020, the Ministry of Djibouti started carrying out a daily press point is held by the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health concerning the cases detected, people cured and deaths. The press briefing is in French, it is translated by Djibouti radio and television into local languages.

description:
The Government of Djibouti has imposed a general, country-wide lockdown, except for essential services.  Traffic has been restricted to a minimum and is only allowed with government authorization.  On April 15, Djiboutian President Ismail Omar Guelleh issued a presidential decree extending the country-wide lock down for another 15 days, until April 30, but it is expected to last longer.  All passenger movement into and out of Djibouti has been suspended and ground, sea, and air borders are closed to passenger traffic. The Djiboutian Ministry of Foreign Affairs has also restricted military and humanitarian flights with personnel. 

 On April 17, the number of laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Djibouti reached 732.  The Djiboutian authorities continue to systematically identify and test contacts through active tracing.  The Djiboutian Ministry of Health confirmed the first fatality of COVID-19 on April 9.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Event: On April 30, 2020 the Government of Djibouti extended the countrywide lockdown through at least May 8, 2020 and the Prime Minister announced a massive campaign to test for COVID-19, stating medical teams will be deploying throughout the country to test as many individuals as possible.

Passenger flights into and out of Djibouti remain suspended. The U.S. government does not anticipate arranging further repatriation flights from Djibouti at this time.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Government of Djibouti has imposed a general, country-wide lockdown, except for essential services.  Traffic has been restricted to a minimum and is only allowed with government authorization.  On April 15, Djiboutian President Ismail Omar Guelleh issued a presidential decree extending the country-wide lock down for another 15 days, until April 30, but it is expected to last longer.  All passenger movement into and out of Djibouti has been suspended and ground, sea, and air borders are closed to passenger traffic. The Djiboutian Ministry of Foreign Affairs has also restricted military and humanitarian flights with personnel. 

 On April 17, the number of laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Djibouti reached 732.  The Djiboutian authorities continue to systematically identify and test contacts through active tracing.  The Djiboutian Ministry of Health confirmed the first fatality of COVID-19 on April 9. UPDATE: Original lockdown was 30th April, it has been extended to 8th of May

description:
Event: On April 30, 2020 the Government of Djibouti extended the countrywide lockdown through at least May 8, 2020 and the Prime Minister announced a massive campaign to test for COVID-19, stating medical teams will be deploying throughout the country to test as many individuals as possible.

Passenger flights into and out of Djibouti remain suspended. The U.S. government does not anticipate arranging further repatriation flights from Djibouti at this time.

Update: On May 10, 2020 the Government of Djibouti issued a 10-page presidential decree extending the country wide lockdown until May 17, 2020 UPDATE: The original lockdown was set to last until May 8, a presidential decree released on May 10 extended the countrywide lockdown until May 17, 2020
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ministry of Health of Djibouti has activated a national coordination mechanism on the 15th of March. This collaboration includes, the government, the ministry of heath, national institution of public health, IOM, WHO, WFP, UNHCR and the UNRC. The coordination platform is chaired by the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health. The platform has several sub-groups working on medical assistance, capacity building, surveillance and communication. In addition, the IOM is conducting from the 25th of March a Population Density Mapping exercise. This will guide public health interventions focusing on the ongoing COVID-19 threats. Several locations have been identified for the PMM, in coordination with national authorities.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The President of Djibouti, on the 31st of March launched an Emergency and Solidarity Fund with an initial state funding of 5.65 million US dollars and called for donations in order to be able to responds to the needs generated by COVID-19 including the purchase of health equipment and the ability to take care of patients.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: In order to keep personnel safe during the COVID-19 pandemic, Camp Lemonnier, Djibouti (CLDJ) and Combined Joint Task Force-Horn of Africa (CJTF-HOA) leadership created and trained a team of service members to disinfect high-usage areas around camp.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: The Ministry of Social Affairs and Solidarities of Djibouti partnered with the WFP on the 29th of March to distribute vouchers to vulnerable populations that are worst hit by COVID-19. Staff deliver vouchers door to door. On the 1st of April, 4000 households received their vouchers to be redeemed at the retailer site.
type_text: The Ministry of Social Affairs and Solidarities and the WFP implemented a policy of distributing food vouchers in order to support those who were affected by the November 2019 floods. These are 4,5000 households who are actually the worst hit by the COVID 19 pandemic. It is done to alleviate some economic and food security difficulties faced by this group
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Ministry of Health in Djibouti, on the 23rd of March, set up a toll free number (1517) for COVID-19 related information and case referrals
The Ministry of Health in Djibouti, from the 23rd of March, has been sending SMS to every local number describing and explaining prevention measures

On the 1st of April, the Ministry of Decentralization in Djibouti organized a coordination meeting with partners on water and satiation. The Ministry and the organizations, such as UNDP and UNICEF, are providing basic hygiene supplies and are raising awareness about Covid 19 in collaboration with the authorities and civil society organizations.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: A presidential decree in Djibouti issues on May 10 announced the reopening of entertainment stores and businesses starting May 17. entertainment stores and businesses include household items and tools hardware stores, bazaars and other stalls, ready-to-wear stores, sewing workshops, appliance stores, libraries, stationery, hairdressing and beauty salons. These businesses have to install a hand washing device at the entrance of their establishment, organize social distancing with a limited number of clients, provide employees with necessary sanitary products, disinfect regularly the premises.
